text: What Are JWT Tokens and How Do They Work?

Have you ever logged into a website or app and wondered how it remembers you without asking for your password every time? Or maybe you've heard developers mention "JWT tokens" and thought, "What exactly are those?"
Let’s simplify the concept and take a closer look at JWT tokens — what they are, why they're used, and how they work.
Traditional Authentication (Cookie + Session)
Before JWTs became popular, websites mostly used sessions and cookies to remember users.
Here’s how a session-based authentication flow works:
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mesons-web/lca-sd/refs/heads/main/Images/img1.png
Problems with Sessions:
Server memory is used to store sessions.
Scaling becomes difficult in distributed systems.
If the server restarts, sessions may be lost.
External session store increases complexity.
Enter JWT (JSON Web Token)
JWT stands for JSON Web Token, a compact and self-contained way to transmit information securely between parties as a JSON object.
Imagine you’re at a party, and the host gives you a wristband. Once you have it, you can access the food and drinks without having to reintroduce yourself. Similarly, JWT is your digital wristband.
JWT Structure
A JWT consists of three parts, separated by dots (.):
Header- Contains metadata about the token itself.
Payload- Contains arbitrary data relevant to the system.
Signature- Used to verify the authenticity of the token.
Each part is Base64URL encoded.

Advantages of JWTs over Sessions
Server storage needed in Sessions but no in JWTs
JWTs are easy to scale across servers
JWTs can be used across different domains
JWT is Stateless Authentication
Use Cases of JWTs
Authentication: After login, server issues a JWT to identify the user.
Authorization: JWT is passed in each request to access protected routes.
Information Exchange: JWTs are signed and optionally encrypted, providing integrity and confidentiality.
